metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of Early Cretaceous magmatic rocks in the Yanhu area of central Tibet
metadata.description: The data in this paper include the major and trace elements of the whole rock, the whole rock SR – nd Pb isotope and zircon u – Pb age and Hf isotope data, and the detrital zircon U-Pb age data. The samples were collected from basalt and andesite in the Salt Lake area of Western Tibet. Zircon U-Pb geochronology and Hf isotope data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock are obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The whole rock SR – nd Pb isotopic compositions were obtained by sample separation and purification and multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The age, origin and formation background of magmatism in the region can be defined by the data obtained.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file: the file name is upb.xls, which represents radioisotope U-Pb data; The file named wrmt.xls represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock; The name of the file is srndpb, which represents the whole rock SR nd Pb isotopic data; Hf.xls represents Hf isotopic data of zircon

literatureList.titleEn: One or Two Early Cretaceous Arc Systems in the Lhasa Terrane, Southern Tibet
literatureList.referenceEn: Li, S.-M., Wang, Q., Zhu, D.-C., Stern, R. J., Cawood, P. A., Sui, Q.-L., & Zhao, Z. (2018). One or Two Early Cretaceous Arc Systems in the Lhasa Terrane, Southern Tibet. Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth, 123(5), 3391-3413. Retrieved from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/2018JB015582. doi:doi:10.1002/2018JB015582

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of geochemical data collected from early Cretaceous igneous rocks in the western salt lake region of Tibet?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major and trace elements, whole-rock Sr–Nd-Pb isotopes, zircon U–Pb ages, zircon Hf isotopes, detrital zircon U-Pb age data, basalts, andesites

Quantification.Question: How many samples of basalt and andesite are included in a dataset related to the geochemical analysis of Early Cretaceous magmatic rocks in western Tibet's salt lake region?
Quantification.Answer: The exact number of samples is not specified.

Definition.Question: What does '锆石U-Pb年代学' mean in the context of data collection methods for geochemical datasets in early Cretaceous magmatic rocks?
Definition.Answer: '锆石U-Pb年代学' refers to a geochronological method used to determine the age of zircon minerals in rocks using U-Pb isotopic dating. In this context, it involves using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to measure the uranium and lead isotopes in zircon samples from early Cretaceous magmatic rocks, helping to define the timing, origin, and geological background of magmatic activity in the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in collecting geochemical data for early Cretaceous magmatic rocks in the western salt lake region of Tibet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in collecting geochemical data for early Cretaceous magmatic rocks in this region may arise from the complexity of accurately measuring whole-rock major and trace elements, as well as isotopic compositions (such as Sr–Nd-Pb) and zircon U–Pb ages and Hf isotopic data. These measurements require precise instrumentation like X-ray fluorescence spectrometers, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometers, and laser ablation techniques, which must be properly calibrated and maintained to ensure accurate results. Additionally, the accessibility of sampling locations and the preservation of sample integrity in the harsh environmental conditions of Tibet can also pose significant difficulties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on geological understanding of the early Cretaceous magmatic activity when using comprehensive geochemical and isotopic datasets collected from volcanic rocks in regions like western Tibet's salt lake area?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By utilizing comprehensive geochemical and isotopic datasets, researchers can better define the timing, origin, and formation context of magmatic activities in western Tibet. This can lead to a more detailed understanding of the geological processes during the early Cretaceous period, including insights into magmatic differentiation, crustal contamination, and mantle source characteristics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind collecting geochemical and isotopic data from magmatic rocks in the salt lake region of western Tibet during the Early Cretaceous?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to determine the age, genesis, and formation background of magmatic activities in the region. This is achieved through analyzing whole-rock major and trace elements, whole-rock Sr–Nd-Pb isotopes, zircon U–Pb ages, and Hf isotopic data, which help in characterizing the magmatic processes and their geological context.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing geochemical and isotopic data from volcanic rock samples in the western Tibet salt lake region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for collecting and analyzing geochemical and isotopic data involve sampling basalt and andesite rocks from the western Tibet salt lake region, followed by the analysis of whole-rock major and trace elements using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. Zircon U-Pb geochronology and zircon Hf isotopic data are obtained through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. Whole-rock Sr–Nd-Pb isotopes are analyzed by sample separation, purification, and multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. These methods help determine the age, genesis, and formation background of magmatic activity in the region.
